title: (PDF) Providencia island in the Colombian Caribbean: X ...
text:
(PDF) Providencia island in the Colombian Caribbean: X marks the spot for a treasure of endemic, migrant and vagrant birds. Neotropical Birding 26: 49-55
ArticlePDF AvailableProvidencia island in the Colombian Caribbean: X marks the spot for a treasure of endemic, migrant and vagrant birds. Neotropical Birding 26: 49-55April 2020Authors: Thomas DoneganThomas DoneganThis person is not on ResearchGate, or hasn't claimed this research yet. Blanca HuertasNatural History Museum London Download full-text PDFRead full-textDownload full-text PDFRead full-textDownload citation Copy link Link copied Read full-text Download citation Copy link Link copiedReferences (21)AbstractColombia has long been much loved by Neotropical birders. But what avian
hoard might lure you to the little-known Caribbean island of Providencia? Discover the world's research25+ million members160+ million publication pages2.3+ billion citationsJoin for freePublic Full-text 1Content uploaded by Thomas DoneganAuthor contentAll content in this area was uploaded by Thomas Donegan on Feb 22, 2022 Content may be subject to copyright.
t h e b i r d i n g m a g a z i n e o f t h e n e o t r o p i c a l b i r d c l u bNumber 26 • Spring 2020Neotropical BirdingNeotropical Birding
The Neotropical Bird Club aims to:• foster an interest in the birds of the Neotropics amongst birdwatchers throughout the world• increase awareness of the importance of support for conservation in the region• mobilise the increasing number of enthusiastic birdwatchers active in the region to contribute to the conservation of Neotropical birds• provide a forum for the publication of articles and notes about Neotropical birds, their identiﬁcation and conservation and thus enhance information exchange in this subject area• channel eﬀorts towards priority species and sites, drawing attention to conservation needs• publicise the activities of local groups and individuals, and improve liaison and collaboration between these same people and other birdwatchersNBC publishes two issues of Neotropical Birding and one issue of Cotinga each year.ISSN 1353-985XUK Registered Charity no. 1040130Please direct correspondence to: Neotropical Bird Club, c/o The Lodge, Sandy, Beds. SG19 2DL, UK Neotropical Birdingthe birding magazine of the neotropical bird clubSenior Editor: James LowenEditorial Committee: Nacho Areta, David Fisher, Raymond Jeﬀers, DanLebbin, Alexander Lees, Robin Restall, Michael Retter and Rob Williams••~••~••~•~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••~••Neotropical Bird Club (NBC)COUNCIL: David Fisher (Chairman), Chris Balchin (Secretary and Advertising), Chris Collins (Treasurer), John Clark, RobClay (Conservation Awards), Mike Dawson, Carl Downing, RobertaGoodall, ManuelSanchez Nivicela, Tom Stuart, Johnirtle, CharlesWilkins and Rob Williams (Representatives).PATRONS: e NBC is delighted to be supported by the following patrons, well known for their contributions to Neotropical ornithology and conservation: Jon Fjeldså, Nancy Hilgert de Benavides and RobertS.Ridgely.CORPORATE SUPPORTERS: ree options (conditions apply): 1 Half-page advert (£250); 2 Full-page advert or two half-page adverts (£400); 3 Full-page advert on back page (£450). For all Corporate Supporter enquiries please e-mail: * advertising@neotropicalbirdclub.orgMEMBERSHIP: Membership of the NBC is open to all, includes a new digital option, and costs: Ordinary£26/$48/€39 (journals in printed form) or £24/$34/€30 (digital only); Family £32/$60/€49 (printed) or £30/$42/€36 (digital); Supporting Member – Ordinary plus a nominated Neotropical national or donation £45/$80/€65 (printed) or £43/$60/€52 (digital); Resident Neotropical National $25 (digital only); Five-year Ordinary Membership £130/$240/€195 (printed only); Life Membership £750/$1400/€1140 (printed only); Libraries & Academic Institutions £55/$100/€81 (printed only). To receive publications both digitally and in hard copy, please add the following costs to the relevant printed-form rate: £5/$7/€6. Secure payment can be made by credit card on the NBC website (seebelow). Alternatively, payments can also be made by cheque in either US Dollars or Sterling, payable to ‘Neotropical Bird Club’. Regrettably, we are unable to accept cheques in Euros. Credit card payments must include the full number, type of card, expiry date, three digit security code and address that appears on the payer’s statement. All payments outside Europe will be charged at US$ rates (to cover extra postage). To join or for further details, please contact the Secretary, NBC, c/o e Lodge, Sandy, Bedfordshire, SG19 2DL, UK or NBC (Membership), Neotropical Bird Club, P.O. Box 1010, Brunswick, ME 04011, USA. E-mail enquiries to: * secretary@neotropicalbirdclub.orgWebsite: http://www.neotropicalbirdclub.orgAdvertise with NBC in Neotropical BirdingAll adverts are printed in full colour. Advertising rates are as follows:• Full page (14 x 21 cm) £450; • Half-page (14 x 10 cm) £300; • Quarter-page(7x10 cm) £200.Deadlines for autumn issue are 15 Feb (booking space) and 15 May (copy). Providencia island in the Colombian Caribbean: X marks the spot for a treasure of endemic, migrant and vagrant birdsThomas Donegan and Blanca HuertasColombia has long been much loved by Neotropical birders. But what avian hoard might lure you to the little-known Caribbean island of Providencia?Colombia includes several far-ﬂung islands within its national territory. ese include two – San Andrés and Providencia – located in the Caribbean, c.200 km east of Nicaragua and c.300–400 km north of Panama. Here a number of bird species can be found that are either very rare vagrants to or absent from the South American mainland. As the islands are a contiguous part of Colombia’s national territory, observations there are countable from the perspective of a Colombian national checklist or lister.San Andrés and Providencia islands are best known for their ‘sea of seven colours’, coral reefs, white-sand beaches and a history related to the infamous pirate or privateer, Captain Henry Morgan. is is also the only part of Colombia where English (of a Creole dialect) is a native language, the islands’ modern status reﬂecting a changing of hands over the centuries between English and Spanish colonial powers. Morgan took Providencia in 1670 on his way to sack Panama, and rumours persist of hidden treasure... but visiting birders will probably have to settle for a treasure trove of endemics and nationally rare migrants!San AndrésSan Andrés is now a well-established hotspot for national rarities during migration periods (McNish 2003, Salaman et al. 2008) and is the only place to see the aptly named and globally Vulnerable San Andres Vireo Vireo caribaeus. As a result, many national and some international birders have been there; and even some bird tours include the island. When we ﬁrst visited San Andrés in the mid-2000s, only a few ﬂights arrived each day and its natural charm could be enjoyed in relative tranquillity. However, the island’s international airport now receives over 20 scheduled ﬂight arrivals daily, mostly 767-range jets, each carrying All photos were taken by Thomas Donegan/Blanca Huertas on Providencia, Colombia, during April 2018. 1 Quintessentially Caribbean beaches of white sand line Providencia’s bays. 49Neotropical Birding 26 >> BIRDING AT THE CUTTING EDGE COLOMBIAN CARIBBEAN
hundreds of tourists. San Andrés remains an excellent birding destination, but no longer oﬀers quite the same pristine nature experience – or the possibility of ﬁnding exciting new records or insights regarding its endemic fauna – that it once did. So step forward Providencia...ProvidenciaProvidencia lies around 80 km north of San Andrés and remains a quiet Caribbean backwater. Whilst San Andrés is essentially a coralline atoll rising to only a few tens of metres above sea level, Providencia has igneous or volcanic origins, with a higher peak (c.150 m) and rugged terrain, giving away to pristine white sandy beaches in its bays (Fig. 1). Both islands are ﬂanked to their east by barrier reefs (Fig. 2). Some authorities trace the reefs north to Belize and consequently regard them as part the world’s second-largest coral reefsystem. Barely 5,000 people live in Providencia’s 22 km2. To date, in contrast to San Andrés, the island has been largely overlooked by mainstream tourism. Moreover, only a few ornithologists or birders have ever visited the island, which is not currently on any bird-tour itinerary. e reasons for this are various. Until the recent recognition by some taxonomic authorities (but not all; see discussion below) of ‘Providencia Vireo V. approximans’ (Fig. 3–4) as a full species, the island was not considered to harbour any endemic bird species. Secondly, it supports fewer Caribbean resident species than San Andrés (Fig. 5). Finally, access is more diﬃcult, time consuming and costly than reaching San Andrés. ere are only two ways to reach Providencia. e ﬁrst is via a daily catamaran service from San Andrés harbour, but this takes up to four hours and is cancelled during inclement weather, which makes planning ahead diﬃcult. Moreover, the crossing can be rough so sickness tablets are recommended. e second option is a ﬂight to Providencia’s small airport, but only light aircraft (carrying c.12 passengers) may land and there are 2 A coral reef lies to the east of Providencia.3–4 ‘Providencia Vireo’ Vireo approximans is Providencia’s star taxon and is common on the island. It is split by the International Ornithological Congress, although other authorities still consider it a subspecies of either Thick-billed Vireo V. crassirostris or Mangrove Vireo V. pallens.2 3450 Neotropical Birding 26 >> BIRDING AT THE CUTTING EDGE COLOMBIAN CARIBBEAN
only up to three ﬂights a day, all from San Andrés and none from the Colombian mainland. In high winds and storms, ﬂights may be cancelled or delayed. ese ﬂights are currently operated only by scheduled provider Satena and charter company Searca, which can be booked through packages sold by the hotel operator Decameron. A ﬂight to San Andrés, for example from Bogotá or Medellín, therefore needs supplementing with another ﬂight or sea journey from San Andrés to Providencia; birding time is lost to travel with either sea or airoption.Providencia (Fig. 6) has more extensive and generally better conserved original vegetation than San Andrés, but its habitats diﬀer considerably, being drier and rockier with fewer palms or mangroves. Santa Catalina (Fig. 7), a smaller and lower-elevation island reached by a footbridge to the north of Providencia, has lusher and greener vegetation, as do mangroves to the east of the island. e coastal regions, southern and eastern parts of Providencia and the main town (aptly named ‘Town’) have suﬀered some habitat conversion for settlement, livestock farming and some budget to mid-range small hotels. However, most of the hills and the predominance of the island’s land mass remain covered by dry scrub andforest. The endemic species and subspecies of Providencia and San AndrésProvidencia hosts several endemic subspecies and (depending on your taxonomic authority of choice) one endemic species. ese are all in species or groups for which San Andrés also hosts endemics (Fig. 5). In some cases, endemic taxa are shared between the two islands and in some cases only one island supports the species or subspecies in question. With most ﬂights to and from San Andrés in the afternoon, a three-day trip (with one full day) should suﬃce to see all the resident taxa.Providencia Vireo For any birder visiting Providencia, its endemic vireo will likely be the main target. Fortunately, this species is common in all habitats and unmissable. However, there are confusingly diﬀerent views on its taxonomic status, with three arrangements in usage:• Subspecies of ick-billed Vireo V. crassirostris. is species is otherwise native to the Bahamas, Turks & Caicos Islands, Cayman Islands, Tortuga and northern Cuba. Until very recently (Chesser et al. 2019), the American Ornithological Society North American Classiﬁcation Committee (NACC, as followed by the Neotropical Bird Club) adopted this taxonomy, which may be why others such as the Howard & Moore (Dickinson & Christidis 2014) and Clements checklists (Clements et al. 2018), plus older Colombian ﬁeld guides (Hilty & Brown 1986, McMullan & Donegan 2014) still adopt this (in our view) ﬂawed historical taxonomy.• Subspecies of Mangrove Vireo V. pallens. is species is otherwise native to Central America. Bond (1961) ﬁrst noted that the voice of Providencia Vireo seems closest to this species. BirdLife International (Brewer 2019, del Hoyo & Collar 2016), some Caribbean ﬁeld guides (Raﬀaele et al. 1998) and now NACC (see above) use this taxonomy, which is (again, in our view) more accurate than placement in 5 Resident avian endemics of Providencia and San AndrésSpecies Providencia subspecies San Andrés subspeciesMangrove Cuckoo Coccyzus minor abbotti abbottiGreen-breasted Mango Anthracothorax prevostii hendersoni pinchoti, often considered a synonym of hendersoniCaribbean Dove Leptotila neoxena lawrenciiYellow (Golden) Warbler Setophaga petechia (sensu stricto)armouri avidaBananaquit Coereba aveola tricolor oblitaBlack-faced Grassquit Tiaris bicolor grandior grandior51Neotropical Birding 26
ick-billed, but conservative and inconsistent with species rank for San Andres Vireo. • Separate species, Providencia Vireo V. approximans. Species rank was aﬀorded in the original description (Ridgway 1884) and is adopted by the International Ornithological Congress (Gill & Donsker 2019), more recent ﬁeld-guide literature (McMullan et al. 2018) and the Colombian checklist (Donegan et al. 2019). is treatment is supported by a recent study which proposed species rank based on vocal, plumage and habitat diﬀerences (Donegan et al. 2015). Wider recognition of species rank for this bird among other authorities is probably only a matter of time.In our short trip during April 2018, we observed and sound-recorded tens of individuals of Providencia Vireo in dry forest, scrub and altered habitats, including in mangroves and seaside growth. It was one of the island’s most widespread passerines, ranging from sea level into the hills. Individuals could even be found alongside roads and in gardens. It seems to be more adaptable and widespread than its counterpart, San Andres Vireo, which is restricted to forest and scrub above sea level and seems absent from mangroves and the coast.Other resident landbirdsJudging from our experience, several resident landbirds that can be relatively hard work on San Andrés – such as White-crowned Pigeon Patagioenas leucocephala, the endemic subspecies of Green-breasted Mango Anthracothorax prevostii hendersoni (Fig. 8), White-winged Dove Zenaida asiatica (Fig. 9) and 66 Coastal forest on Providencia.7 The island of Santa Catalina (foreground) lies just north of Providencia (background) and is accessed via a footbridge.Resident landbirds that are hard to see on San Andrés but easier on Providencia include 8 the endemic subspecies of Green-breasted Mango Anthracothorax prevosti hendersoni and 9 White-winged Dove Zenaida asiatica.7 96852 Neotropical Birding 26 >> BIRDING AT THE CUTTING EDGE COLOMBIAN CARIBBEAN
Caribbean Elaenia Elaenia martinica (Fig.10) – are all comparatively common, indeed abundant, on Providencia; all occur in both primary and modiﬁed habitats throughout the island. e resident endemic subspecies of Bananaquit Coereba ﬂaveola tricolor (Fig. 11) and Black-faced Grassquit Tiaris bicolor grandior (Fig. 12) are unmissable, even occuring along the coastal road in gardens and scrub. e Bananaquits of Providencia and San Andrés, as on some other Caribbean islands, have an extensive red gape: this striking feature is not shared by mainland South American populations.ree resident endemic subspecies require particular eﬀort to locate. To see Black-whiskered Vireo Vireo altiloquus grandior (Fig. 13) and Mangrove Cuckoo Coccyzus minor abbotti, ventures are needed to the island’s interior. One of the best locations to try is the reservoir or represa ( 13°20’35.8”N 81°23’15.0”W) which can be accessed via an uphill dirt road from Freshwater Bay ( 13°20’44.7”N 81°23’34.0”W) on the west coast. is location also gives good opportunities for seeing aquatic birds, migrants and most of the endemic and non-endemic resident species. e longer walk to e Peak ( 13°20’49.0”N 81°22’27.5”W), which at 150 m altitude gives good views over the whole island and its seas, can be accessed from Bottom House ( 13°19’53”N, 81°22’37”W) in the south of the island and should also give opportunities to see both species. Yellow (Golden) Warbler Setophaga petechia is represented on Providencia by subspecies armouri, a particularly well-marked form with olive tertials and, in adult males, an almost solid red-orange breast (Donegan & Huertas 2018). It is worth paying special attention to this taxon in future studies. For decades it was lost to science, but there have been several recent records – including a recent photograph on eBird by Vanburen Ward Bolivar on 13 May 2017 (eBird checklist S36828771; ML 57968261) which conﬁrms a remarkable rediscovery. All records are from the small (c.50 ha) area of mangroves near the airport. is tract of mangrove habitat forms just under 10% of the mostly oceanic Parque Nacional Natural McBean Lagoon. e mangroves can be accessed by hiring a kayak from Posada Cocobay 10 Vocalisations of Caribbean Elaenia Elaenia martinica cinerescens on Providencia differ somewhat from those on San Andrés. The whole species may benet from taxonomic revision.Resident endemic subspecies of 11 Bananaquit Coereba aveola tricolor and 12 Black-faced Grassquit Tiaris bicolor grandior are unmissable on Providencia.13 The ‘other’ endemic Providencia vireo taxon, Black-whiskered Vireo Vireo altiloquus grandior, is less ashy than its star congener and can be a challenge to nd. This may be the rst published photograph of this population in life.1210131153Neotropical Birding 26
(in the Maracaibo part of the island;  13°22’36”N, 81°21’16”W) or via small tour operators. A fee to Parques Nacionales is payable, which operators or hotels can organise.Care must be taken to distinguish resident ‘Golden’ Warblers from the migratory (Northern) Yellow Warbler S. p. aestiva group. e underparts of adult male Yellow Warbler show red streaking on a yellow base, but not the red-to-orange breast band characteristic of Golden Warbler. e population of the endemic subspecies armouri is apparently restricted to the Providencia airport mangroves and must sadly number only a few tens. Were Red List assessments applied to subspecies, it would probably qualify as Critically Endangered. Its already small area of habitat is under threat due to airport-expansion plans, to which local communities have objected, fearing replication of the eﬀects of mass tourism observed in San Andrés. More endemics to come?During our brief study, we collated sound-recordings of almost all species of resident landbird; for many, these were not previously available. We have compared our sound-recordings to those made on San Andrés and elsewhere on 8 xeno-canto.org. Based on this initial review, the local Caribbean Elaenia population (taxon cinerescens, whose type locality is on Providencia; Fig. 10) stood out, appearing to be diﬀerentiated in certain vocal variables from the San Andrés population (which is usually placed in the same subspecies). is species as a whole requires further taxonomic study, which could lead to the recognition of at least one more island-endemic subspecies each for both Providencia and San Andrés and possible splits within the broader species grouping.A migrant and vagrant hotspotDuring spring and autumn, Providencia and San Andrés are hotspots for nationally rare migrants and vagrants. e islands are Colombia’s equivalent of the UK’s Scilly Isles or Shetland, or the Aleutians in the US, acting as a magnet for passage migrants tiring as they cross the sea. Several bird species can be seen regularly here which, in mainland Colombia, are very rare vagrants. ese include Worm-eating Warbler Helmitheros vermivorum, Yellow-throated Warbler Setophaga dominica, Palm Warbler S. palmarum and Grey Catbird Dumetella carolinensis. In our short study, we found several nationally scarce migrants, such as Chimney Swift Chaetura pelagica, Magnolia Warbler S. magnolia and Cape May Warbler S. tigrina and observed the migrant Antillean Nighthawk Chordeiles gundlachii, a species previously reported on San Andrés (McNish 2003) but not accepted by some as a valid record (Avendaño et al. 2017). Recent national ﬁrsts for Colombia recorded on Providencia include Double-crested Cormorant Phalacrocorax auritus (Salaman et al. 2008) and Red-breasted Merganser Mergus serrator (Ward-Bolivar & Lasso-Zapata 2012). Doubtless there will be more to come!SeabirdsProvidencia is the largest island of a small archipelago. A cluster of three islets, the Tres Hermanos, supports a spectacular breeding colony of Magniﬁcent Frigatebird Fregata magniﬁcens plus Brown Booby Sula leucogaster (Fig. 14). Historically, Audubon’s Shearwater Puﬃnus lherminieri used to breed on nearby Crab Cay. However, we found no such colony there, and the species is reported by Parques Nacionales staﬀ to have relocated to a more distant smaller island, which is out of bounds to tourists. Seawatching at appropriate times of year or by boat is probably necessary to observe this nationally scarce seabird and others. Not just birdsAs well as its birds, the reptiles of Providencia are special. ere is an astonishing abundance and diversity of large lizards (Fig. 15) in particular, perhaps related to the island’s arid climate. Some can be quite conﬁding and several are endemic (McNish 2003). Visitors might feel as if they are on the Galapagos Islands!1414 There is a breeding colony of Magnicent Frigatebird Fregata magnicens (here with breeding Brown Booby Sula leucogaster in the foreground) on the Tres Hermanos islets.54 Neotropical Birding 26 >> BIRDING AT THE CUTTING EDGE COLOMBIAN CARIBBEAN
Final thoughtsTravelling to Providencia involves some travel expense and time, which may mean that many visitors prefer not to venture beyond the comforts of San Andrés. However, there must be few places left in the world where it is possible to get so far away from tourist crowds on pristine white-sand beaches and coral reefs – and particularly in a place with such potential for productive birding in terms of nationally rare birds, new island records and glorious endemics.ACKNOWLEDGMENTSanks to James Lowen for encouraging us to write this article and to our son Lucas for sharing the visit and helping us to keep good notes.REFERENCESAvendaño, J. Note that Jorge Avendano's name (unlike those of the authors) appears prominently on the cover but he wrote a foreword and is not an author.ViewShow abstractLista de chequeo de las aves de Colombia: Una síntesis del estado del conocimiento desde Hilty & Brown (1986)ArticleFull-text availableOct 2017 Jorge Enrique AvendañoClara Isabel Bohórquez Loreta Rosselli Luis Miguel RenjifoLa taxonomía y conocimiento de la distribución de la avifauna colombiana ha sufrido grandes cambios desde la publicación de “A Guide to the Birds of Colombia” por Hilty & Brown (1986), a tal punto que hoy no se sabe con precisión cuántas y cuáles especies de aves existen en el territorio colombiano. Presentamos la lista de chequeo de la avifauna de Colombia a agosto de 2017 con base en la revisión de 340 referencias relacionadas con la distribución de la avifauna colombiana. En total, reportamos 1909 especies de aves para el territorio continental e insular del país, de las cuales 216 han sido adicionadas principalmente a partir de 1986. Aunque existe información novedosa sobre distribución para cerca del 66% de la avifauna colombiana, la mayoría de las publicaciones (87%) y registros (53%) se concentran al occidente de la cordillera Oriental (región transandina). Con base en esta información identificamos aquellas áreas del país con vacíos de conocimiento que ameritan mayor interés por parte de los investigadores. Además, estimulamos a la comunidad ornitológica a publicar la información inédita represada, al igual que mejorar la evidencia que soporta los registros novedosos para el país.ViewShow abstractHBW and BirdLife International Illustrated Checklist of the Birds of the World. It is a complete checklist whose taxonomy incorporates the most up-to-date information and an exhaustive methodology (Tobias et al. 2010) in an entirely systematic and consistent way. At the same time, it contains illustrations and distribution maps for every bird species in the world. Donegan Alonso Quevedo Juan Verhelst Paul SalamanSubtropical Pygmy-Owl Glaucidium parkeri, Fiery-tailed Awlbill Avocettula recurvirostris and Pale-rumped Swift Chaetura egregia are added to Colombia's bird checklist based on photographic records. Band-rumped Storm-Petrel Oceanodroma castro, Golden-spangled Piculet Picumnus exilis, Yellow-bellied Flycatcher Empidonax flaviventris and Yellow-throated Tanager Iridisornis analis are all elevated to the status of confirmed species occurring on the mainland, also following photographic records. We considered taxonomic proposals by del Hoyo & Collar (2014) using Tobias et al. (2010)'s "species scoring system". We studied possible changes relevant to Colombia in detail, based on new studies of vocalisations, our own fieldwork data and published molecular studies. We conclude that the following proposed Trochilidae (hummingbird) splits are supported by differentiation in voice: White-throated Wedgebill Schistes albogularis from Geoffroy's Wedgebill S. geoffroyi (Wedge-billed Hummingbird); Longuemare's Sunangel Heliangelus clarisse and Merida Sunangel H. spencei from Amethystine Sunangel Heliangelus amethysticollis; White-tailed Hillstar Urochroa leucura from Rufous-gaped Hillstar U. bougeri; and Humboldt's Sapphire Amazilia humboldtii from Gray's Sapphire A. grayi. In light of these positive assessments, we accepted proposed splits of morphologically distinctive hummingbirds in a little-vocalising genus: Perija Starfrontlet Coeligena consita and Golden Starfrontlet C. eos from Golden-bellied Starfrontlet C. bonapartei and Green Inca C. conradii from Collared Inca C. torquata. We adopt the proposed split of Double-banded Puffbird Hypnelus bicinctus from Rufous-throated Puffbird H. ruficollis, highlighting vocal differences. We suggest transfer of subspecies striaticollis to the bicinctus group. We split Splendid Woodpecker Campephilus splendens from C. haematogaster based on differences in voice, plumage, distribution and drumming behaviour. Carribean Coot Fulica caribaea is lumped with American Coot F. americana on account of widely reported intergradation. After studying vocal differentiation in three genera, we reject 10 proposed splits in Ramphastidae (toucans) of forms which either intergrade with one another or which are not as vocally distinct as sympatric toucans. Our vocal analyses instead suggest that the Groove-billed Toucanet subspecies Aulacorhynchus sulcatus erythrognatus of Venezuela may merit species rank. The widely adopted split of Andean Duck Oxyura ferruginea from Ruddy Duck O. jamaicensis is again rejected, due to well-documented intergradation in Colombia. We conclude that del Hoyo & Collar (2014)'s taxonomy has been useful and worthwhile in drawing attention to novel taxonomic situations, especially in Trochilidae. However, we suggest using the Tobias et al. (2010) system as a point of reference and not a sole criterion to determine taxonomic rank. After analysis of sound recordings of putative related species, we conclude that Providencia Vireo V. approximans merits species rank. We split the Blossomcrowns Anthocephala. Several amendments to genus and species names, English names and linear order are made, following recent publications. The Colombian checklist increases again to 1,921 species (excluding escapes), of which 1,846 are documented by 'confirmed' records on the mainland.ViewShow abstractThe Howard and Moore complete checklist of the birds of the world, 4th. ed., Vol. 2BookFull-text availableJan 2014 Edward C. Donegan Blanca HuertasWe present details of various interesting migratory bird records recorded on Isla Providencia (Old Providence island) in April 2018. These include apparently the first records for the island of Chimney Swift Chaetura pelagica and Antillean Nighthawk Chordeiles gundlachii and the first confirmed record of Purple Martin Progne subis. We also discuss a record of migratory individuals (aestiva group) of the Yellow Warbler Setophaga petechia, and their identification compared to the local endemic resident subspecies armouri, of the Golden Warbler (petechia) group. Finally, we present details of other records of migrant or non-endemic species, including photographic records of several species. 2018 Fundacion ProAves Carrera. Abstract We present details of a recent spate of records of Egyptian Goose Alopochen aegyptiaca a new species for Colombia, all occurring after 2014.
